choices.text: It is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis, affecting mostly the nasal mucosa and extending to the larynx and bronchi.
The disease primarily affects the southern parts of India and mostly females above 50 years of age.
The granulomatous stage is characterized by painful ulcerative nodules and nasal bleeding.
Treatment consists only of surgical correction for nasal deformity without any antibiotic therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about rhinoscleroma is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis, affecting mostly the nasal mucosa and extending to the larynx and bronchi.

 

 

Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by the Gram-negative bacillus Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis (Frisch bacillus). The disease typically starts in the nose and can extend to the nasopharynx, oropharynx, larynx (especially subglottic region), trachea, and bronchi. It affects both sexes and all ages, with a higher incidence in northern India.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. The disease primarily affects the southern parts of India and mostly females above 50 years of age. Incorrect. The disease is endemic in several parts of the world and is seen more often in the northern parts of India than the southern parts. It affects both sexes and any age group, not specifically females above 50.

 

Option C. The granulomatous stage is characterized by painful ulcerative nodules and nasal bleeding: Incorrect. In the granulomatous stage, painless, non-ulcerative granulomatous nodules form in the nasal mucosa with subdermal infiltration causing a “woody” feel to the lower external nose and upper lip. Painful ulcerative nodules and bleeding are not typical features.

 

Option D. Treatment consists only of surgical correction for nasal deformity without any antibiotic therapy: Incorrect. Treatment requires a combination of antibiotics, specifically streptomycin and tetracycline for at least 4–6 weeks, and is repeated if necessary until cultures from biopsy material become negative. Steroids may be added to reduce fibrosis. Surgical treatment is only for airway management and correcting deformity, not the sole treatment.

 

Additional facts:

 

  • The disease progresses through three stages: atrophic (foul-smelling purulent nasal discharge and crusting), granulomatous (painless nodules and woody infiltration), and cicatricial (stenosis, nasal deformity, adhesions, and possible subglottic stenosis causing respiratory distress).
  • Diagnosis is by biopsy showing plasma cells, lymphocytes, eosinophils, Mikulicz cells (large foam cells with bacilli), and Russell bodies (eosinophilic inclusion bodies in plasma cells).
  • Mikulicz cells and Russell bodies are diagnostic of rhinoscleroma.

 

 

Miculikz cells

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous infection caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis affecting nasal and respiratory mucosa, diagnosed by biopsy showing Mikulicz cells, and treated with prolonged streptomycin and tetracycline therapy along with possible surgical intervention.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 156

choices.text: Foul-smelling purulent nasal discharge with crusting resembling atrophic rhinitis
Painless, nonulcerative granulomatous nodules in nasal mucosa with subdermal “woody” infiltration of the lower external nose and upper lip
Nasal septal perforation with severe nasal bleeding and ulceration
Subglottic stenosis causing respiratory distress without any nasal deformity

questions.text: Which of the following clinical features is characteristic of the granulomatous stage of rhinoscleroma?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Painless, nonulcerative granulomatous nodules in nasal mucosa with subdermal “woody” infiltration of the lower external nose and upper lip

 

The granulomatous stage is marked by the formation of painless, nonulcerative granulomatous nodules in the nasal mucosa. Additionally, subdermal infiltration of the lower part of the external nose and upper lip gives a characteristic “woody” feel.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Foul-smelling purulent nasal discharge with crusting resembling atrophic rhinitis: Incorrect. This describes the atrophic stage of rhinoscleroma, which resembles atrophic rhinitis and is characterized by foul-smelling purulent nasal discharge and crusting.

 

Option C. Nasal septal perforation with severe nasal bleeding and ulceration: Incorrect. Ulceration and severe nasal bleeding are not typical features of rhinoscleroma; the nodules are usually painless and nonulcerative. Nasal septal perforation is more commonly seen in other diseases like Wegener’s granulomatosis.

 

Option D. Subglottic stenosis causing respiratory distress without any nasal deformity: Incorrect. Subglottic stenosis causing respiratory distress is a feature of the cicatricial stage of rhinoscleroma, which also involves adhesions and distortion of nasal and pharyngeal structures. Nasal deformity is usually present by this stage.

 

Additional facts:

 

  • Rhinoscleroma is caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis, a Gram-negative bacillus, and is endemic in many parts of the world, especially the northern parts of India.
  • The disease affects both sexes and all age groups.
  • It progresses through three stages: atrophic, granulomatous, and cicatricial.
  • Early recognition and treatment can prevent progression to the cicatricial stage and its complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The granulomatous stage of rhinoscleroma is characterized by painless, nonulcerative granulomatous nodules with subdermal “woody” infiltration of the lower nose and upper lip.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 156

choices.text: Initiate streptomycin and tetracycline for at least 4–6 weeks
Perform surgical excision immediately without culture

questions.text: A 32-year-old man from northern India presents with progressive nasal obstruction, crusting, and nasal deformity. Biopsy of the nasal mucosa reveals infiltration of submucosa by plasma cells, lymphocytes, eosinophils, and large foamy cells with vacuolated cytoplasm and central nuclei. These cells are found to contain Gram-negative bacilli. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Initiate streptomycin and tetracycline for at least 4–6 weeks

 

The biopsy findings describe Mikulicz cells, which are large foamy macrophages with vacuolated cytoplasm containing Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis. Along with Russell bodies (eosinophilic immunoglobulin inclusions in plasma cells), these are pathognomonic for rhinoscleroma. First-line treatment includes streptomycin (1 g/day) and tetracycline (2 g/day) for 4–6 weeks, repeated if necessary. Treatment is stopped only after two consecutive cultures from biopsy material are negative.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Start high-dose corticosteroids as monotherapy: Incorrect. Corticosteroids can be used as adjuncts to reduce fibrosis but *are not sufficient alone.

 

Option C. Begin anti-tubercular therapy empirically: Incorrect. There is no role for anti-tubercular therapy in rhinoscleroma, which is caused by a Gram-negative bacillus, not Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

 

Option D. Perform surgical excision immediately without culture: Incorrect. Surgery may be needed after medical therapy to relieve airway obstruction or correct deformity, but immediate excision without culture and antibiotics is not appropriate initial management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rhinoscleroma is confirmed by biopsy showing Mikulicz cells and Russell bodies, and is treated with streptomycin and tetracycline for 4–6 weeks, with therapy continued until two negative cultures are obtained.

 

Ref:  P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 156

choices.text: Primary nasal syphilis commonly presents as a painless gumma causing septal destruction and saddle nose deformity.
Secondary nasal syphilis is often associated with mucous patches in the pharynx, skin rash, fever, and generalized lymphadenitis.
Tertiary nasal syphilis typically manifests as primary chancre localized to the nasal vestibule.
Hard palate perforation and offensive nasal discharge are features exclusive to congenital nasal syphilis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about nasal involvement in syphilis is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Secondary nasal syphilis is often associated with mucous patches in the pharynx, skin rash, fever, and generalized lymphadenitis.

 

Secondary nasal syphilis, although rarely recognized, presents as simple rhinitis with crusting and fissuring in the nasal vestibule. Diagnosis is suggested by mucous patches in the pharynx, skin rash, fever, and generalized lymphadenitis.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Primary nasal syphilis commonly presents as a painless gumma causing septal destruction and saddle nose deformity: Incorrect. The painless gumma with septal destruction and saddle nose deformity occurs in tertiary syphilis, not primary. Primary nasal syphilis presents as a chancre in the nasal vestibule and is rare.

 

 

Option C. Tertiary nasal syphilis typically manifests as primary chancre localized to the nasal vestibule: Incorrect. Primary syphilis manifests as a primary chancre of the nasal vestibule, not tertiary syphilis. Tertiary stage causes destructive gummatous lesions.

 

Option D. Hard palate perforation and offensive nasal discharge are features exclusive to congenital nasal syphilis: Incorrect. Hard palate perforation and offensive nasal discharge with crusting and bony/cartilaginous sequestra occur in tertiary syphilis and are not exclusive to congenital cases.

 

Additional facts:

 

  • Nasal syphilis includes acquired and congenital types.
  • The nose is most commonly involved in the tertiary stage of acquired syphilis.
  • Septal perforation in tertiary syphilis involves both bony and cartilaginous parts, causing saddle nose deformity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Secondary nasal syphilis presents with mucous patches in the pharynx, skin rash, fever, and lymphadenitis, whereas tertiary syphilis causes gummatous destruction leading to septal perforation and saddle nose deformity.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 157

The late form usually appears in infancy and is characterized by mucous patches and generalized lymphadenitis.
Diagnosis is mainly clinical and does not require serological testing or biopsy.
Treatment consists of benzathine penicillin given once, with no need for repeated doses.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about congenital syphilis involving the nose is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The early form presents within the first 3 months of life with “snuffles,” purulent nasal discharge, and excoriation of the nasal vestibule and upper lip.

 

Congenital syphilis has two forms affecting the nose: the early form manifests in the first 3 months of life as “snuffles,” with purulent nasal discharge, fissuring, and excoriation of the nasal vestibule and upper lip.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. The late form usually appears in infancy and is characterized by mucous patches and generalized lymphadenitis: Incorrect. The late form usually manifests around puberty and resembles tertiary acquired syphilis with gummatous destruction of nasal structures, along with stigmata like corneal opacities, deafness, and Hutchinson’s teeth—not mucous patches or generalized lymphadenitis.

 

 

Option C. Diagnosis is mainly clinical and does not require serological testing or biopsy: Incorrect. Diagnosis is confirmed by serological tests such as VDRL and biopsy with special staining to demonstrate Treponema pallidum. Clinical features alone are insufficient.

 

Option D. Treatment consists of benzathine penicillin given once, with no need for repeated doses: Incorrect. Treatment requires benzathine penicillin 2.4 million units intramuscularly every week for 3 weeks (total dose 7.2 million units), not a single dose. Nasal crusts should be removed by irrigation, and sequestra excised. Cosmetic corrections are done after disease inactivity.

 

Additional facts:

 

  • Nasal deformity in late congenital syphilis is similar to tertiary syphilis with destruction by gummas.
  • Early removal of crusts and sequestra helps prevent further damage.
  • Other late congenital signs include corneal opacities, sensorineural deafness, and Hutchinson’s teeth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital syphilis presents early as “snuffles” with purulent nasal discharge and excoriations, while late manifestations mimic tertiary syphilis; diagnosis relies on serology and biopsy, and treatment is benzathine penicillin given weekly for three weeks.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 157

choices.text: Primary tuberculosis of the nose is common and usually involves the posterior nasal septum.
Nasal tuberculosis commonly presents with nodular infiltration followed by ulceration and perforation of the cartilaginous part of the anterior nasal septum.
Diagnosis is made clinically without the need for biopsy or special staining.
Treatment of nasal tuberculosis primarily involves surgical excision of the affected tissue.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about nasal tuberculosis is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nasal tuberculosis commonly presents with nodular infiltration followed by ulceration and perforation of the cartilaginous part of the anterior nasal septum.

 

Nasal tuberculosis typically begins with nodular infiltration and progresses to ulceration and perforation of the cartilaginous portion of the anterior nasal septum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary tuberculosis of the nose is common and usually involves the posterior nasal septum: Incorrect. Primary tuberculosis of the nose is rare; nasal involvement is more often secondary to pulmonary tuberculosis. The anterior part of the nasal septum and anterior end of the inferior turbinate are the common sites involved, not the posterior septum.

 

Option C. Diagnosis is made clinically without the need for biopsy or special staining: Incorrect. Diagnosis requires biopsy with special staining for acid-fast bacilli and culture of the causative organisms; clinical examination alone is insufficient.

 

Option D. Treatment of nasal tuberculosis primarily involves surgical excision of the affected tissue: Incorrect. Treatment is primarily with antitubercular drugs; surgery is not the mainstay of treatment.

 

Additional facts:

 

  • Nasal tuberculosis is a rare presentation but important to diagnose due to its association with systemic disease.
  • Early diagnosis and treatment prevent complications like septal perforation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nasal tuberculosis is usually secondary to lung disease, presenting with nodular infiltration followed by ulceration and perforation of the anterior nasal septum, diagnosed by biopsy and acid-fast staining, and treated with antitubercular therapy.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 157

The characteristic skin lesion is a brown, gelatinous nodule known as an “apple-jelly” nodule.
Tubercle bacilli are easily isolated by culture from nasal lesions.
Treatment involves surgical excision of the affected area without antitubercular drugs.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about lupus vulgaris involving the nose is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The characteristic skin lesion is a brown, gelatinous nodule known as an “apple-jelly” nodule.

 

The skin lesions of lupus vulgaris characteristically appear as brown, gelatinous nodules referred to as “apple-jelly” nodules. In the nasal vestibule, it presents as chronic vestibulitis. Perforation can occur in the cartilaginous part of the nasal septum.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is a high-grade tuberculous infection primarily affecting the posterior nasal septum: Incorrect. Lupus vulgaris is a low-grade tuberculous infection that commonly affects the nasal vestibule or skin of the nose and face, not specifically the posterior nasal septum.

 

Option C. Tubercle bacilli are easily isolated by culture from nasal lesions: Incorrect. It is difficult to isolate tubercle bacilli by culture from lupus vulgaris lesions, making biopsy more useful for diagnosis.

 

Option D. Treatment involves surgical excision of the affected area without antitubercular drugs: Incorrect. Treatment is the same as for tuberculosis of the nose, which involves antitubercular drug therapy, not surgical excision alone.

 

Additional facts:

 

  • Biopsy of the lesion aids diagnosis due to difficulty in culturing the organism.
  • Early diagnosis and treatment prevent nasal septal perforation and deformity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lupus vulgaris is a low-grade tuberculous infection of the nasal vestibule and skin characterized by “apple-jelly” nodules, diagnosed by biopsy, and treated with standard antitubercular therapy.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 157

Early nasal symptoms include excessive nasal discharge with red, swollen mucosa, progressing to crusting, bleeding, and possible septal perforation.
Diagnosis is made by detecting acid-fast bacilli in granulomas rich in Langhans giant cells.
Treatment includes prolonged therapy with penicillin and erythromycin.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about nasal involvement in leprosy is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Early nasal symptoms include excessive nasal discharge with red, swollen mucosa, progressing to crusting, bleeding, and possible septal perforation.

 

 

Infection starts in the anterior nasal septum and anterior end of the inferior turbinate. Early symptoms include excessive nasal discharge with redness and swelling of the mucosa, followed by crusting and bleeding. Nodular lesions on the septum may ulcerate, causing perforation. Late sequelae include atrophic rhinitis, depression of the nasal bridge, and destruction of the anterior nasal spine with retrusion of the columella.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Nasal involvement is more common in tuberculoid leprosy than lepromatous leprosy: Incorrect. Nasal involvement is more common in the lepromatous form of leprosy than in tuberculoid or dimorphous forms.

 

Option C. Diagnosis is made by detecting acid-fast bacilli in granulomas rich in Langhans giant cells: Incorrect. Diagnosis involves detecting acid-fast lepra bacilli in foamy histiocytes called lepra cells, not Langhans giant cells which are typical of tuberculosis.

 

Option D. Treatment includes prolonged therapy with penicillin and erythromycin: Incorrect. Treatment consists of multidrug therapy with dapsone, rifampin, and isoniazid, not penicillin and erythromycin.

 

Additional facts:

 

  • Biopsy and nasal mucosal scrapings help in diagnosis by demonstrating lepra bacilli.
  • Surgical reconstruction is done after the disease becomes inactive to correct deformities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nasal involvement in leprosy, predominantly lepromatous type, presents with nasal discharge, crusting, bleeding, and septal perforation, diagnosed by lepra bacilli in nasal scrapings, and treated with multidrug therapy including dapsone and rifampin.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 158

questions.text: A 26-year-old man from Tamil Nadu presents with nasal obstruction and recurrent episodes of epistaxis. On anterior rhinoscopy, a pinkish, polypoidal mass with a leafy surface and white dots is seen attached to the lateral nasal wall. It bleeds easily on touch. A biopsy is sent for evaluation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rhinosporidiosis

 

Rhinosporidiosis is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi. It is endemic in southern India and presents as a vascular, pink to purple, leafy polypoidal mass in the nose or nasopharynx. The mass bleeds on touch and has characteristic white dots (sporangia) on its surface. Biopsy shows large sporangia filled with endospores.

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Nasal polyposis: Incorrect. Nasal polyps are usually pale, non-vascular, and do not bleed easily. They are not associated with white dots (sporangia) or a leafy appearance.

 

 

Option C. Inverted papilloma: Incorrect. Inverted papillomas arise from the lateral nasal wall and may be polypoidal, but they do not show sporangia or characteristic white dots. Histologically, they show invaginated epithelium, not endospores.

 

 

Option D. Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener’s granulomatosis): Incorrect. Granulomatosis with polyangiitis may cause nasal crusting, septal perforation, or a mass lesion, but it is typically associated with systemic symptoms, positive c-ANCA, and granulomatous vasculitis on biopsy—not sporangia or fungal elements.

 

Additional facts:

 

  • The disease is acquired through contaminated pond water shared with animals.
  • The organism has not been cultured or successfully transferred to experimental animals.
  • Treatment is surgical excision with cauterization of the base. Recurrences are common. Dapsone has been tried with variable success.
  • The life cycle includes trophic stage, sporangium development, and endospore release.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rhinosporidiosis presents as a vascular, polypoidal nasal mass with white dots (sporangia), is endemic in southern India, diagnosed by biopsy showing endospore-filled sporangia, and treated with surgical excision and cautery.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 158

choices.text: It is a well-classified fungus that can be routinely cultured in the laboratory
The disease is rare in India and mostly seen in European countries
The organism is difficult to classify, considered by some to be a protozoan or fish parasite from the DRIP clade
The infection primarily spreads through respiratory droplets between humans

questions.text: A 35-year-old agricultural worker from Chhattisgarh presents with a complaint of nasal obstruction and occasional epistaxis. He reports frequent bathing in local ponds used by both people and animals. On nasal examination, a polypoidal, vascular mass with white spots is seen. A diagnosis of rhinosporidiosis is considered. Which of the following statements is true regarding the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The organism is difficult to classify, considered by some to be a protozoan or fish parasite from the DRIP clade

 

The etiologic agent Rhinosporidium seeberi has an uncertain classification. Some researchers now consider it to be related to aquatic parasites of the DRIP clade (Dermocystidium, Rosette agent, Ichthyophonus, and Psorospermum), which are pathogens of fish and amphibians.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. It is a well-classified fungus that can be routinely cultured in the laboratory: Incorrect. Rhinosporidium seeberi was initially thought to be a fungus, but it has not been cultured so far and is difficult to classify definitively. Hence, it is not a routinely culturable fungus.

 

Option B. The disease is rare in India and mostly seen in European countries: Incorrect. Rhinosporidiosis is not rare in India. In fact, most cases are reported from India, Sri Lanka, and Pakistan, especially in southern Indian states such as Tamil Nadu, Kerala, Andhra Pradesh, Chhattisgarh, and Puducherry.

 

Option D. The infection primarily spreads through respiratory droplets between humans: Incorrect. Rhinosporidiosis is not transmitted via respiratory droplets. The mode of infection is through exposure to contaminated stagnant water, often shared by both humans and animals such as cows, horses, and dogs.

 

Additional facts:

 

  • The disease primarily affects the nose and nasopharynx but may involve other mucocutaneous sites.
  • The white dots on the mass represent sporangia, which contain endospores.
  • Human and animal cohabitation of infected ponds is a major risk factor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rhinosporidium seeberi, the causative agent of rhinosporidiosis, is an unculturable organism likely related to aquatic protozoa in the DRIP clade, and the disease is endemic in southern India with waterborne transmission.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 159

choices.text: The trophic stage is when the organism releases mature spores into surrounding tissue under high pressure.
The sporangium is formed after the trophocyte matures and is characterized by a thick wall with outer cellulose and inner chitinous layers.
Sporangia measure up to 250 μm, contain thousands of endospores, and release them by rupturing or gradual extrusion.
After endospore liberation, the cycle terminates unless a new host is infected.

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes the life cycle of Rhinosporidium seeberi, the causative organism of rhinosporidiosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sporangia measure up to 250 μm, contain thousands of endospores, and release them by rupturing or gradual extrusion.

 

 

A mature sporangium measures 200–250 μm, contains 12,000–16,000 endospores, and releases them either by rupturing under high internal pressure or gradually through the germinal pore if the pressure is low. After liberation, these endospores begin the cycle again as trophic forms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The trophic stage is when the organism releases mature spores into surrounding tissue under high pressure: Incorrect. The trophic stage is the initial phase of the life cycle, where the endospore enlarges, and nuclear division leads to the formation of immature endospores. Release occurs at a later stage from mature sporangia, not in the trophic stage.

 

Option B. The sporangium is formed after the trophocyte matures and is characterized by a thick wall with outer cellulose and inner chitinous layers: Incorrect. The sporangium indeed develops after the trophocyte stage, but it has a thick wall composed of an outer chitinous layer and an inner cellulose layer (the reverse of what's stated in this option).

 

Option D. After endospore liberation, the cycle terminates unless a new host is infected: Incorrect. The life cycle continues locally as endospores re-enter the trophic stage. Some spores may disseminate via lymphatics or bloodstream, potentially leading to disseminated rhinosporidiosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rhinosporidium seeberi completes a life cycle that includes trophic stage, sporangium formation (with thousands of endospores), and endospore release either by rupture or gradual extrusion, followed by recurrence of the trophic stage.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 159

questions.text: A 24-year-old male from Andhra Pradesh presents with complaints of persistent nasal stuffiness and occasional episodes of epistaxis. He frequently bathes in local ponds shared with livestock. On anterior rhinoscopy, a pinkish-purple, leafy polypoidal mass is seen attached to the nasal septum. The surface of the mass is studded with white dots and it bleeds easily on touch. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rhinosporidiosis

 

Rhinosporidiosis presents with a pink to purple, leafy, polypoidal mass that is highly vascular, bleeds on touch, and is often studded with white dots, which represent sporangia. The disease is acquired through contaminated pond water, often shared with animals. Common early symptoms include blood-tinged nasal discharge, nasal stuffiness, and occasionally frank epistaxis.

 

 

Other Options: 

Option A. Inverted papilloma: Incorrect. Inverted papilloma typically arises from the lateral nasal wall and is associated with nasal obstruction, but it is not as vascular and does not have the characteristic white dots (sporangia) or epistaxis seen in rhinosporidiosis.

 

 

Option B. Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma: Incorrect. Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is a highly vascular tumor typically seen in adolescent males, presenting with profuse epistaxis and nasopharyngeal mass, but not a leafy or polypoidal mass with sporangia.

 

 

Option D. Allergic nasal polyp: Incorrect. Allergic nasal polyps are pale, nonvascular, and do not bleed easily. They also lack the characteristic sporangia seen on the surface of a rhinosporidial mass.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rhinosporidiosis presents with a vascular, polypoidal nasal mass studded with white sporangia, bleeds easily, and is associated with pond water exposure in endemic areas.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 159

choices.text: Nasal polyp due to allergic rhinitis

questions.text: A 30-year-old man from Kerala presents with complaints of progressive nasal obstruction and occasional nasal bleeding. He reports frequent bathing in village ponds shared with animals. On examination, a pinkish-purple, polypoidal mass with a leafy surface is seen attached to the nasal septum, studded with white spots and bleeds on touch. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rhinosporidiosis

 

Rhinosporidiosis is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi, commonly acquired through contaminated water in ponds shared with animals. The typical clinical feature is a vascular, pink to purple, leafy polypoidal mass attached to the nasal septum or lateral wall, bleeds easily on touch, and has white dots on the surface representing sporangia. The mass may extend to the nasopharynx and can cause nasal stuffiness, blood-tinged discharge, or epistaxis.

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma: Incorrect. Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma typically affects adolescent males, presents with profuse epistaxis, and arises from the sphenopalatine foramen, not the nasal septum or lateral wall. It is also not studded with white dots.

 

 

Option B. Nasal polyp due to allergic rhinitis: Incorrect. Nasal polyps are usually pale, non-vascular, and do not bleed on touch. They are associated with allergic rhinitis, not pond water exposure or white sporangia.

 

 

Option D. Inverted papilloma: Incorrect. Inverted papilloma is a benign but potentially aggressive tumor arising from the lateral nasal wall. While it may present as a polypoidal mass, it does not bleed easily or have white dots indicative of sporangia.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rhinosporidiosis presents with a vascular, polypoidal nasal mass studded with white dots (sporangia), commonly acquired through pond water, and may cause nasal obstruction, blood-tinged discharge, or epistaxis.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 159

questions.text: A 55-year-old diabetic male on immunosuppressive therapy following renal transplantation presents with symptoms of nasal obstruction and headache for one week. On anterior rhinoscopy, a greenish/grayish material is seen over the nasal mucosa. Exploration of the maxillary sinus reveals a semisolid, cheesy black material. Histopathology shows fungal elements on special staining. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aspergillus species

 

Aspergillus (commonly A. niger, A. fumigatus, or A. flavus) causes fungal sinusitis, especially in immunocompromised individuals. The clinical picture of subacute sinusitis, grayish nasal membrane, and a fungus ball with cheesy-white or black material in the maxillary sinus is characteristic. Diagnosis is confirmed by special fungal stains, and treatment includes debridement and antifungals such as Amphotericin B.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candida albicans: Incorrect. Though it can cause mucosal infections in immunocompromised hosts, it usually presents with white curd-like patches in the oral cavity or esophagus, not blackish debris or nasal membrane.

 

Option B. Mucor species: Incorrect. Mucormycosis typically presents more aggressively with rapid tissue necrosis, black eschar, facial swelling, and orbital involvement. While it affects immunocompromised patients, the presence of a “fungus ball” and slow-progressing symptoms favor Aspergillosis.

 

Option D. Cryptococcus neoformans: Incorrect. This yeast mainly affects the central nervous system (meningitis) in immunocompromised patients and does not typically present with nasal symptoms or sinus involvement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aspergillosis presents with black or gray nasal membrane and a fungus ball of cheesy-black material in the sinuses, especially in immunocompromised individuals; caused by species like A. niger, A. fumigatus, or A. flavus.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 159

choices.text: Start oral fluconazole and observe for response
Begin intravenous amphotericin B and urgent surgical debridement
Administer corticosteroids to reduce local inflammation
Prescribe oral antibiotics for bacterial sinusitis

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus presents to the emergency department with complaints of facial pain, nasal congestion, and swelling around the left eye. On examination, he is febrile, and a black necrotic mass is seen in the left nasal cavity with destruction of the nasal septum and hard palate. MRI reveals involvement of the ethmoid sinus and extension toward the orbit. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Begin intravenous amphotericin B and urgent surgical debridement

 

Mucormycosis is a rapidly progressing angioinvasive fungal infection, typically seen in immunocompromised individuals like uncontrolled diabetics. Hallmark findings include black necrotic tissue in the nasal cavity and rapid spread to adjacent structures (orbit, brain). Treatment requires aggressive surgical debridement and systemic antifungal therapy with IV amphotericin B. Additionally, control of the underlying risk factor (e.g., hyperglycemia) is essential.

 

 

Option A. Start oral fluconazole and observe for response: Incorrect. Fluconazole is not effective against mucormycosis. It is mainly used for Candida infections. Delaying definitive therapy can lead to rapid progression and death.

 

Option C. Administer corticosteroids to reduce local inflammation: Incorrect. Corticosteroids will worsen the immunosuppression and are contraindicated in fungal infections like mucormycosis. They may exacerbate the infection and delay recovery.

 

Option D. Prescribe oral antibiotics for bacterial sinusitis: Incorrect. While the presentation may mimic bacterial sinusitis, the presence of black necrotic tissue and rapid progression in a diabetic patient strongly suggests invasive fungal sinusitis. Antibiotics have no role in treating mucormycosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mucormycosis in uncontrolled diabetics presents with black necrotic nasal mass and requires urgent surgical debridement with IV amphotericin B.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 159

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with a 3-month history of persistent nasal crusting, blood-stained nasal discharge, and nasal obstruction. He reports fatigue, joint pains, and a recent episode of haemoptysis. On examination, there is a saddle nose deformity and septal perforation. Chest X-ray shows multiple cavitary lesions. Urinalysis reveals red blood cells and casts, with elevated serum creatinine. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Wegener’s granulomatosis

 

Wegener’s granulomatosis (now called Granulomatosis with polyangiitis) is a systemic vasculitis involving upper airways, lungs, and kidneys. Nasal crusting, saddle nose, septal perforation, cavitary lung lesions, and renal findings like red cell casts and raised creatinine are classical. Biopsy reveals necrotizing granulomatous inflammation and vasculitis. Treatment is with systemic steroids and cytotoxic agents like cyclophosphamide or azathioprine.

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Tuberculosis: Incorrect. While TB can cause haemoptysis and cavitary lung lesions, it does not typically cause nasal septal perforation, saddle nose, or renal involvement with red cell casts. It also lacks the characteristic granulomatous vasculitis of small vessels seen in biopsy.

 

Option C. Rhinoscleroma: Incorrect. Rhinoscleroma is a chronic bacterial infection caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis, which presents with a slow-growing nasal mass and woody induration. It does not involve the lungs, kidneys, or show cavitary lesions or systemic vasculitis.

 

Option D. Nonhealing midline granuloma: Incorrect. This is a clinical term used to describe idiopathic destructive lesions of the midface, but unlike Wegener’s, it does not involve systemic features like lung or renal involvement. Histology also differs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wegener’s granulomatosis presents with nasal crusting, saddle nose, cavitary lung lesions, and renal failure; confirmed by biopsy showing necrotizing granulomatous vasculitis and treated with steroids and cytotoxic drugs.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 160

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with a progressively destructive lesion over the left side of the nose involving the upper lip and adjacent oral cavity. There are no systemic symptoms such as cough, haematuria, or arthralgia. Histopathology shows polymorphic lymphoid infiltrate with angiocentric and angioinvasive features but no evidence of vasculitis. Immunohistochemistry confirms a T-cell origin. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) T-cell lymphoma

 

T-cell lymphoma (previously called midline malignant lesion or polymorphic reticulosis) is a rapidly destructive lesion affecting midline facial structures such as nose, upper lip, oral cavity, and sometimes orbit. It lacks systemic involvement and does not show vasculitis on biopsy. Diagnosis is confirmed with immunohistochemistry. Localized disease is treated with radiotherapy, while disseminated disease requires chemotherapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wegener’s granulomatosis: Incorrect. Though Wegener’s also causes nasal destruction, it typically presents with systemic involvement (lung, kidneys), positive c-ANCA, and histologically shows necrotizing granulomatous vasculitis. In contrast, the absence of vasculitis and systemic features here makes Wegener’s unlikely.

 

Option C. Nasal tuberculosis: Incorrect. Nasal TB is rare and typically causes ulcerative or granulomatous lesions but is less destructive, and biopsy would show caseating granulomas, not angiocentric lymphoid infiltrates.

 

Option D. Nonhealing midline granuloma: Incorrect. This is a clinical term that describes destructive midline lesions but is not a definitive diagnosis. T-cell lymphoma is one specific histopathological entity under this umbrella.

 

Educational Objective:

 

T-cell lymphoma is a rapidly destructive midline lesion without systemic involvement or vasculitis, confirmed by immunohistochemistry and treated with radiotherapy or chemotherapy.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 160

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with nasal obstruction, pain, and occasional epistaxis for the past few weeks. On examination, submucosal nodules are seen over the nasal septum and inferior turbinate. She also has facial skin nodules. Chest X-ray reveals bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy with diffuse interstitial infiltrates. Laboratory results show elevated serum and urinary calcium levels. Biopsy of a nasal lesion reveals non-caseating granulomas. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sarcoidosis

 

Sarcoidosis is a systemic granulomatous disorder of unknown etiology. Nasal involvement includes submucosal nodules on the septum or inferior turbinate, causing obstruction, pain, or epistaxis. It often shows non-caseating granulomas on biopsy, hilar lymphadenopathy on chest X-ray, and raised serum/urinary calcium levels. Treatment involves systemic corticosteroids; nasal symptoms may respond to topical steroid sprays

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tuberculosis: Incorrect. Though TB is also a granulomatous disease, histology shows caseating granulomas, unlike the non-caseating granulomas of sarcoidosis. TB is less likely to present with facial nodules and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy on X-ray as the primary finding.

 

Option C. Leprosy: Incorrect. Leprosy can involve the nasal mucosa but presents with thickened skin, anesthesia, and acid-fast bacilli on biopsy. It does not show non-caseating granulomas or raised calcium levels.

 

Option D. Rhinoscleroma: Incorrect. Caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis, this condition leads to woody swelling and a slow-growing mass. Histology shows Mikulicz cells, not non-caseating granulomas. Hilar lymphadenopathy and hypercalcemia are not features.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sarcoidosis presents with non-caseating granulomas, nasal nodules, hilar lymphadenopathy, and raised calcium levels, and is treated with systemic and local steroids.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 160.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male from a rural area presents with long-standing nasal obstruction and foul-smelling purulent discharge. On examination, there is crusting in the nasal cavity and a firm, woody swelling over the nasal bridge. Biopsy reveals submucosal infiltration by plasma cells, lymphocytes, eosinophils, Mikulicz cells, and Russell bodies. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rhinoscleroma

 

Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis (Frisch bacillus), common in rural populations. It progresses through 3 

 

Stages:

 

  1. Atrophic stage – foul-smelling discharge and crusting,
  2. Granulomatous stage – firm woody nodules (woody/Hebra nose),
  3. Cicatricial stage – fibrosis with adhesions and nasal stenosis (tapir nose).
    Biopsy findings include plasma cells, eosinophils, Mikulicz cells (foamy macrophages with bacteria), and Russell bodies (eosinophilic plasma cell inclusions). Treatment includes Streptomycin, Tetracycline, Rifampicin, Ciprofloxacin, steroids for fibrosis, and surgery for stenosis repair.

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Rhinosporidiosis: Incorrect. Rhinosporidiosis presents with a vascular, polypoidal nasal mass studded with white dots (sporangia) and bleeds easily on touch. It is caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi, and histology shows large sporangia—not Mikulicz or Russell bodies.

 

 

Option C. Nasal tuberculosis: Incorrect. TB usually presents with ulceration and granulomas showing caseating necrosis, not woody swelling or Mikulicz cells.

 

Option D. Leprosy: Incorrect. Leprosy may affect nasal mucosa, but biopsy shows acid-fast bacilli, not Mikulicz or Russell bodies. Also, woody induration is not a typical feature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rhinoscleroma is a chronic nasal granulomatous disease caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis, characterized by woody nodules, Mikulicz cells, and treated with antibiotics and surgery.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 156

questions.text: A 28-year-old man from a coastal village presents with complaints of progressive nasal obstruction and blood-tinged nasal discharge. He reports frequent bathing in local ponds. On examination, a pinkish-purple, polypoidal mass resembling a strawberry is seen in the nasal cavity. The mass is vascular and bleeds on touch. Biopsy shows large sporangia with spores bursting through chitinous walls. What is the most appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rhinosporidiosis

 

Rhinosporidiosis is caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi, now classified under protozoa (previously thought to be fungal). It commonly affects individuals exposed to pond water, especially in coastal regions. The characteristic clinical appearance is a leafy, vascular, pink-to-purple polypoidal mass in the nasal cavity that bleeds on touch—often described as “strawberry-like.” Diagnosis is confirmed by biopsy, showing sporangia with chitinous walls bursting to release endospores. Treatment is diathermy excision with base cauterization, and dapsone is used to prevent recurrence.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nasal polyposis: Incorrect. Nasal polyps are pale, non-vascular, and usually associated with allergy. They do not bleed easily on touch and are not linked to pond water or sporangial pathology.

 

 

Option C. Inverted papilloma: Incorrect. Inverted papilloma is a benign but potentially aggressive tumor arising from the lateral nasal wall, often unilateral. It can mimic polyps but lacks the strawberry-like vascularity and sporangia seen in rhinosporidiosis.

 

 

Option D. Rhinoscleroma: Incorrect. Caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis, this presents with a woody swelling, not a vascular polyp. Histology shows Mikulicz cells and Russell bodies, not sporangia.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rhinosporidiosis presents as a pink to purple, strawberry-like, bleeding nasal mass due to Rhinosporidium seeberi, diagnosed by biopsy and treated with surgical excision and dapsone.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 156

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the ENT clinic with a painless ulcer over the nasal septum and complaints of nasal congestion and mild discharge for 2 weeks. On examination, there is a clean-based, indurated ulcer on the anterior septum. He has no history of trauma, allergy, or prior nasal surgery. Further questioning reveals a history of unprotected sexual contact 3 weeks ago. A VDRL test is positive. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Primary syphilis

 

Primary syphilis commonly presents with a chancre — a painless, indurated ulcer — most often on the genitals, but it can occur at extragenital sites including the nasal septum in cases of direct inoculation. The timing (3 weeks after sexual exposure) and presence of a clean ulcer with positive VDRL strongly suggest primary syphilis of the nasal septum.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Secondary syphilis: Incorrect. Secondary syphilis presents 6–8 weeks after the chancre and is characterized by mucocutaneous lesions, diffuse rash (including palms/soles), and systemic symptoms. Nasal symptoms in secondary syphilis include thick discharge and vestibular fissures—not a solitary chancre.

 

Option C. Tertiary syphilis: Incorrect. Tertiary syphilis presents years later and causes gummas leading to destructive lesions like saddle nose deformity or septal perforation—not a solitary ulcer.

 

 

Option D. Rhinosporidiosis: Incorrect. Rhinosporidiosis presents with a bleeding, strawberry-like polypoidal mass due to Rhinosporidium seeberi. It is not a painless ulcer and has a different exposure history (pond bathing).

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary syphilis can present as a painless ulcer (chancre) on the nasal septum following direct inoculation, and diagnosis is supported by positive serology like VDRL.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 160

questions.text: A 29-year-old man presents to the ENT outpatient department with a chronic, non-healing ulcer over the anterior nasal septum for the past 2 months. He also reports occasional blood-tinged nasal discharge and crusting. On examination, there is a pale ulcer over the cartilaginous septum with signs of erosion. No significant lymphadenopathy is noted. A biopsy of the lesion reveals granulomatous inflammation with Langhans-type giant cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ulcerative tuberculosis of the nose

 

This form commonly affects the cartilaginous septum or inferior turbinate, presenting with non-healing ulcers and potential septal perforation. Granulomatous histology with Langhans giant cells supports a tubercular etiology. Diagnosis is confirmed by biopsy, and treatment is with anti-tubercular therapy (ATT).

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Lupus vulgaris: Incorrect. Lupus vulgaris, the nodular form of nasal tuberculosis, typically presents with apple-jelly nodules in the nasal vestibule, which do not blanch on pressure. The case described is ulcerative with septal involvement rather than nodular.

 

 

Option C. Rhinoscleroma: Incorrect. Rhinoscleroma, caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis, presents as a woody swelling with nasal obstruction and crusting. Histology shows Mikulicz cells and Russell bodies, not Langhans giant cells.

 

 

Option D. Wegener’s granulomatosis (Granulomatosis with polyangiitis): Incorrect. GPA can cause septal perforation and granulomatous inflammation but is usually associated with systemic features (renal involvement, pulmonary infiltrates) and positive c-ANCA serology.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ulcerative nasal tuberculosis typically involves the cartilaginous septum or inferior turbinate, presenting with non-healing ulcers and septal perforation, confirmed by biopsy and treated with ATT.

 

Ref: Dhingra PL, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, 6th Edition, pg 160

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a 2-month history of persistent nasal crusting, purulent nasal discharge, and intermittent epistaxis. She also complains of increasing shortness of breath and hematuria for the past 1 week. On examination, there is septal perforation with saddle-nose deformity. Chest X-ray reveals bilateral patchy infiltrates. Urinalysis shows red blood cell casts, proteinuria, and microscopic hematuria. Blood work reveals anemia, elevated ESR, and positive cytoplasmic-ANCA (c-ANCA). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Wegener’s Granulomatosis (Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis)

 

This patient has classic features: nasal ulceration with septal perforation, saddle-nose deformity, purulent nasal discharge, and recurrent epistaxis. She also has pulmonary infiltrates and renal involvement (hematuria, RBC casts), pointing to multisystem vasculitis. Positive c-ANCA and biopsy showing necrotizing granulomatous vasculitis are diagnostic. First-line treatment is cyclophosphamide and corticosteroids.

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Rhinoscleroma: Incorrect. Rhinoscleroma presents with woody swelling of the nose, often with nasal crusting and nasal obstruction. However, it is not associated with systemic involvement such as pulmonary or renal symptoms. Biopsy shows Mikulicz cells and Russell bodies, not necrotizing vasculitis.

 

 

Option C. Tuberculosis of the nose: Incorrect. Nasal tuberculosis may present with ulceration and discharge, but it does not typically involve the lungs and kidneys in this fashion. Also, c-ANCA is not positive in tuberculosis.

 

 

Option D. Allergic fungal rhinosinusitis (AFRS): Incorrect. AFRS causes nasal obstruction, allergic mucin, and polypoidal changes, usually in atopic individuals. It is not associated with systemic vasculitis, hematuria, or c-ANCA positivity.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wegener’s granulomatosis (GPA) presents with nasal crusting, septal perforation, pulmonary infiltrates, and renal involvement, confirmed by c-ANCA and biopsy showing necrotizing granulomatous vasculitis.

 

Ref: Dhingra PL, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, 6th Edition, pg 160

questions.text: A 42-year-old male presents with progressive nasal obstruction, recurrent epistaxis, and foul-smelling crusting for the past 3 months. On examination, there is ulceration and necrosis over the nasal septum with destruction of mid-facial structures. Biopsy reveals angiocentric and angiodestructive infiltrate composed of atypical lymphoid cells positive for CD56. EBV is detected within tumor cells by in-situ hybridization. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Midline Lethal Granuloma (NK/T-cell lymphoma)

 

This is a high-grade extranodal NK/T-cell lymphoma affecting the nasal cavity and midface. Presents with nasal obstruction, epistaxis, and destructive midfacial lesions. Biopsy shows angiocentric infiltration and necrosis, tumor cells are CD56+, and EBV is present in the tumor cells. Treatment involves chemoradiotherapy and surgical reconstruction, but prognosis remains poor.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wegener’s Granulomatosis: Incorrect. While GPA can cause nasal ulceration, septal perforation, and even saddle nose, angiocentric necrosis, CD56 positivity, and EBV positivity are not characteristic. c-ANCA would typically be positive, and renal/pulmonary involvement is often seen.

 

 

Option C. Rhinoscleroma: Incorrect. Caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis, this presents with woody swelling, not necrosis or facial destruction. Histology reveals Mikulicz cells and Russell bodies, not CD56+ lymphoid cells.

 

 

Option D.  Nasal Tuberculosis: Incorrect. TB of the nose causes ulcers, crusting, and rarely septal perforation. However, it does not cause extensive necrosis, facial destruction, or show CD56/EBV positivity on histology.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Midline lethal granuloma is a destructive NK/T-cell lymphoma with CD56 and EBV positivity, presenting with midfacial necrosis and requiring chemoradiotherapy.

 

Ref: Dhingra PL, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, 6th Edition, pg 160

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents with chronic nasal obstruction, anosmia, and crusting of the nasal mucosa for the past 3 months. She also reports fatigue, dry cough, and unintentional weight loss. On examination, she has a violaceous swelling over the nasal tip. Nasal endoscopy reveals strawberry-like mucosa and septal perforation. Chest X-ray shows bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. ACE levels are elevated. Nasal mucosal biopsy shows non-caseating granulomas with asteroid bodies. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sarcoidosis

 

Sarcoidosis is a multisystem granulomatous disorder. The patient has nasal obstruction, crusting, anosmia, and lupus pernio (violaceous nasal swelling). Biopsy shows non-caseating granulomas with asteroid bodies, which is classic. Elevated ACE levels, bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, and constitutional symptoms further support the diagnosis.

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Wegener’s Granulomatosis (GPA): Incorrect. GPA may present with nasal crusting and septal perforation, but it typically shows necrotizing vasculitis and is c-ANCA positive. Granulomas are usually necrotizing, unlike the non-caseating granulomas seen here.

 

 

Option C. Nasal Tuberculosis: Incorrect. TB typically causes caseating granulomas, nasal ulcers, and may result in septal perforation. However, ACE elevation, asteroid bodies, and hilar adenopathy are not features of TB.

 

 

Option D. Rhinoscleroma: Incorrect. Rhinoscleroma, caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis, involves woody swelling and crusting, especially in the nasal vestibule. Histology shows Mikulicz cells and Russell bodies, not granulomas or asteroid bodies.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sarcoidosis can involve the nasal mucosa and present with crusting, anosmia, septal perforation, and lupus pernio; diagnosis is confirmed by non-caseating granulomas on biopsy and elevated ACE levels.

 

Ref: Dhingra PL, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, 6th Edition, pg 160

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with a 4-month history of unilateral nasal obstruction, intermittent blood-stained nasal discharge, and occasional epistaxis. He has no history of allergy or trauma. On nasal endoscopy, a mass is visualized in the middle meatus region. CT scan shows a unilateral soft tissue mass involving the lateral nasal wall without bony destruction. Biopsy reveals hyperplastic epithelium growing inward into the stroma. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inverted papilloma

 

Inverted papilloma (aka Schneiderian papilloma / Ringertz tumor) is a benign but locally aggressive tumor of the nasal cavity, arising most commonly from the middle meatus on the lateral nasal wall. It is associated with HPV infection, occurs more in males aged 40–70, and shows endophytic growth (inversion into stroma) on biopsy. It presents with unilateral nasal obstruction, discharge, and epistaxis. CT/MRI assesses extent; medial maxillectomy is the treatment of choice.

 

 

Other Options: 

Option B. Nasal polyposis: Incorrect. Nasal polyps are bilateral, pale, edematous growths associated with allergy or chronic rhinosinusitis. They are not associated with inward stromal growth or epistaxis and do not typically arise from the middle meatus as a vascular, aggressive mass.

 

 

Option C. Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma: Incorrect. Occurs in adolescent males, not in middle-aged adults. Presents with recurrent epistaxis, nasal obstruction, and can show bony remodeling. Arises from sphenopalatine foramen, not the middle meatus.

 

 

Option D. Esthesioneuroblastoma: Incorrect. Rare neuroectodermal tumor from olfactory epithelium, presents with anosmia, epistaxis, and proptosis. It occurs near the cribriform plate, not from lateral wall/middle meatus, and shows rosettes on biopsy, not papillomatous epithelium.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inverted papilloma presents with unilateral nasal obstruction and epistaxis, arises from the lateral nasal wall, and is diagnosed by inward epithelial growth on biopsy; medial maxillectomy is the treatment of choice.

 

Ref: Dhingra PL, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, 6th Ed., pg 202

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with a 4-month history of progressive unilateral nasal obstruction, occasional epistaxis, and mucopurulent nasal discharge. He also complains of watering of the right eye and double vision over the past week. On anterior rhinoscopy, a reddish, fleshy mass is seen in the right middle meatus. CT scan reveals a soft tissue lesion involving the lateral nasal wall with extension into the orbit. A biopsy of the lesion shows papillomatous epithelium growing inward into the stroma. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inverted papilloma

 

Also called Schneiderian papilloma, Transitional cell papilloma, or Ringertz tumor, it arises from the non-olfactory nasal mucosa (Schneiderian membrane), most commonly from the lateral wall in the middle meatus. The hallmark histology is inversion of the papillomatous epithelium into the stroma. Seen predominantly in males aged 40–70, it presents with unilateral nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, and epistaxis. If the tumor extends to the orbit, it can cause proptosis, diplopia, and lacrimation. Etiology is linked to Human Papilloma Virus (HPV).

 

 

Option B. Nasal polyp: Incorrect. Nasal polyps are bilateral, pale, and non-vascular. They do not typically arise from the middle meatus or show stromal invasion on histology. Polyps do not cause orbital symptoms.

 

 

Option C. Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA): Incorrect. JNA is a vascular tumor seen in adolescent males, not older adults. It arises from the sphenopalatine foramen, not the lateral wall. It causes profuse epistaxis and nasopharyngeal mass, not stromal inversion on biopsy.

 

 

Option D. Esthesioneuroblastoma: Incorrect. This rare tumor arises from the olfactory epithelium near the cribriform plate, not the Schneiderian membrane. It may cause proptosis and anosmia but shows rosette formation on histology, not stromal inversion.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inverted papilloma arises from the Schneiderian membrane of the lateral nasal wall, shows inward stromal growth, is linked to HPV, and presents with unilateral nasal symptoms and possible orbital extension in older males.

 

Ref: Dhingra PL, Diseases of Ear, Nose & Throat, 6th Edition, pg 202

choices.text: Functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS) with simple polypectomy
Medial maxillectomy via endoscopic or open approach
Radiotherapy to reduce tumor size before surgery
Observation and repeat biopsy after 3 months

questions.text: A 62-year-old male with a prior history of nasal polypectomy presents with recurrent unilateral nasal obstruction and occasional epistaxis. On nasal endoscopy, a pale polypoidal mass is seen in the right middle meatus, resembling a nasal polyp. CT scan reveals a mass lesion in the nasal cavity extending into the maxillary sinus. MRI helps distinguish the mass from retained sinus secretions. A biopsy confirms inverted papilloma. The lesion appears to approach the orbit. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Medial maxillectomy via endoscopic or open approach

 

Medial maxillectomy is the treatment of choice for inverted papilloma, especially when there is extension into adjacent sinuses or orbit. It can be performed via endoscopic, lateral rhinotomy, or sublabial degloving approach. Endoscopic techniques are preferred today due to reduced morbidity. Wider external approaches may be needed for tumors involving the orbit or frontal sinus.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. FESS with simple polypectomy: Incorrect. Although the lesion resembles a polyp and may have been previously mistaken for one, simple polypectomy is inadequate for inverted papilloma. The tumor has a tendency for recurrence and local invasion, hence requires more extensive surgical excision.

 

Option C. Radiotherapy: Incorrect. Radiotherapy is not advised in inverted papilloma as it may induce malignant transformation. It is neither first-line nor adjunctive unless associated malignancy is confirmed.

 

Option D. Observation and repeat biopsy: Incorrect. Once a confirmed diagnosis of inverted papilloma is made, definitive surgical excision is indicated. Observation delays management and increases risk of progression or malignant transformation (seen in 10–15% cases).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inverted papilloma mimics nasal polyp but requires biopsy for diagnosis and is best treated with medial maxillectomy; radiotherapy is contraindicated due to risk of malignancy.

 

Ref: Dhingra PL, Diseases of Ear, Nose & Throat, 6th Edition, pg 202

choices.text: Attempt removal with forceps under local anesthesia
Remove using a blunt hook under general anesthesia with cuffed endotracheal tube
Irrigate the nasal cavity to flush the foreign body out

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought to the ENT outpatient clinic with a history of unilateral, foul-smelling nasal discharge for 3 days. The mother denies any history of trauma or recent illness. On anterior rhinoscopy, a rounded foreign body is suspected in the right nasal cavity. The child is anxious and uncooperative during examination. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Remove using a blunt hook under general anesthesia with cuffed endotracheal tube

 

Rounded foreign bodies are best removed using a blunt hook, which can be passed beyond the object and pulled forward. In young or uncooperative children, this should be done under general anesthesia with a cuffed ET tube to prevent aspiration into the tracheobronchial tree. Rose’s position is also preferred for better access and airway protection.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Attempt removal with forceps under local anesthesia: Incorrect. Forceps are typically used for paper, cotton, or soft swab-type foreign bodies, which can be grasped and extracted. In this case, the foreign body is rounded (like a bead or button), which may slip during grasping, making forceps inappropriate.

 

Option C. Observe and allow spontaneous expulsion: Incorrect. Foreign bodies rarely come out spontaneously. Delaying removal increases risk of nasal infections, sinusitis, and rhinolith formation, and possibly aspiration.

 

Option D. Irrigate the nasal cavity to flush the foreign body out: Incorrect. Irrigation is contraindicated in nasal foreign bodies, especially if the type is unknown or if the child is uncooperative, due to the risk of pushing the object into the airway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Unilateral foul-smelling nasal discharge in a child suggests nasal foreign body; rounded objects require removal by blunt hook under general anesthesia with a cuffed endotracheal tube to prevent aspiration.

 

Ref: Dhingra PL, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, 6th Ed., pg 203

questions.text: A 7-year-old child is brought with complaints of unilateral nasal obstruction and foul-smelling discharge from the right nostril for several months. The discharge occasionally contains blood. On anterior rhinoscopy, a grey-brown mass with an irregular surface and stony hard consistency is visualized. Attempted manipulation causes a portion of the mass to break off. A plain X-ray (as shown) reveals a radio-opaque mass in the nasal cavity. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rhinolith

 

A rhinolith is a stone-like mass formed by deposition of calcium and magnesium salts around a foreign body in the nasal cavity. It presents with unilateral nasal obstruction, foul-smelling (often blood-tinged) discharge, and appears as a grey-brown or greenish-black irregular mass with a hard, brittle feel. Parts may break during manipulation. Radiologically, it is radio-opaque and surgical removal under general anesthesia is often required.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nasal polyp: Incorrect. Polyps are pale, soft, non-tender, and usually bilateral, with no radio-opacity or hard consistency. They do not bleed easily unless secondarily infected.

 

 

Option C. Inverted papilloma: Incorrect. Inverted papillomas are usually seen in older males, arise from the middle meatus, and are unilateral, but are soft-tissue masses, not calcified, and do not present with hard, brittle texture or break on manipulation.

 

 

Option D. Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA): Incorrect. JNA occurs in adolescent males, typically presents with profuse epistaxis and nasal obstruction, arises from sphenopalatine foramen, and does not calcify to appear radio-opaque.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rhinolith presents as a hard, brittle, radio-opaque mass in the nasal cavity due to mineral deposition over a foreign body, causing foul-smelling unilateral nasal discharge and requires surgical removal under GA.

 

Ref: Dhingra PL, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, 6th Edition, pg 203

choices.text: Chrysomya species; irrigation with chloroform water or turpentine oil
Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis; doxycycline and surgical excision

questions.text: A 65-year-old homeless man presents with complaints of severe foul-smelling nasal discharge, irritation, and a crawling sensation in the nose for the past 2 days. He has a history of poor hygiene and chronic nasal infections. On examination, multiple maggots are seen moving on the nasal mucosa. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism and appropriate first-line treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chrysomya species; irrigation with chloroform water or turpentine oil

 

Nasal myiasis is caused by flies, especially Chrysomya species, laying eggs on infected nasal mucosa which hatch within 24 hours. It presents with foul-smelling nasal discharge and visible maggots. Management includes the use of chloroform water or turpentine oil to kill and dislodge maggots.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis; doxycycline and surgical excision: Incorrect. This is the organism causing rhinoscleroma, which presents with woody nasal swelling and crusting, not with maggots or foul discharge. Histology shows Mikulicz cells, not maggots.

 

Option C. Rhinosporidium seeberi; cauterization and dapsone: Incorrect. This causes rhinosporidiosis, characterized by vascular, polypoidal masses in the nasal cavity that bleed on touch. It is treated with surgical excision and dapsone, not with turpentine oil.

 

Option D. Leishmania donovani; amphotericin B: Incorrect. This causes visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar), not nasal infestation. Symptoms include fever, hepatosplenomegaly, pancytopenia, not maggots in the nose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nasal myiasis is caused by Chrysomya fly larvae on infected mucosa, presenting with foul nasal discharge and maggots, treated with chloroform water or turpentine oil.

 

Ref: Dhingra PL, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, 6th Ed., pg 203

choices.text: Nasal synechiae; surgical separation and placement of silastic sheet
Rhinoscleroma; long-term antibiotics and surgical debridement

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with complaints of nasal obstruction and difficulty breathing through her nose, particularly after undergoing septoplasty 2 months ago. Anterior rhinoscopy reveals adhesion between the septum and the lateral nasal wall. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis and appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nasal synechiae; surgical separation and placement of silastic sheet

 

Nasal synechiae are adhesions between the septum and lateral nasal wall, commonly occurring after septal surgery, polypectomy, foreign body removal, fracture reduction, endoscopic sinus surgery, or intranasal packing. Treatment involves removal of the synechiae and placement of a silastic or cellophane sheet between raw surfaces to prevent recurrence.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nasal polyp; endoscopic polypectomy: Incorrect. Nasal polyps are pale, edematous masses, not adhesions. They do not typically occur post-surgery and are not resolved by separating mucosal surfaces.

 

 

Option C. Rhinoscleroma; long-term antibiotics and surgical debridement: Incorrect. Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous infection due to Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis, not post-surgical adhesions. Presents with woody swelling, not obstruction from adhesions.

 

 

Option D. Inverted papilloma; medial maxillectomy: Incorrect. Inverted papilloma is a benign but aggressive tumor with inward stromal growth, typically arising from the middle meatus, not a post-surgical adhesion.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nasal synechiae are adhesions between raw mucosal surfaces after nasal surgeries or trauma, treated by separation and placement of silastic or cellophane sheet to prevent recurrence.

 

Ref: Dhingra PL, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, 6th Ed., pg 203

choices.text: Squamous papilloma; local excision with cauterization of the base
Nasal polyp; oral corticosteroids and saline nasal irrigation
Inverted papilloma; medial maxillectomy via endoscopic approach
Rhinosporidiosis; wide excision and dapsone therapy

questions.text: A 48-year-old male presents with a slow-growing, wart-like lesion in the right nasal vestibule for the past 2 months. The lesion is pedunculated, non-tender, and not associated with bleeding. On anterior rhinoscopy, it resembles a verrucous growth, similar to a skin wart, arising from the lower part of the nasal septum. What is the most likely diagnosis, and the best approach to treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Squamous papilloma; local excision with cauterization of the base

 

Squamous papillomas are verrucous lesions resembling skin warts, arising from the nasal vestibule or lower part of the septum. They may be single or multiple, pedunculated or sessile, and are treated with local excision and base cauterization to prevent recurrence. Cryosurgery or laser can also be used.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nasal polyp; oral corticosteroids and saline nasal irrigation: Incorrect. Nasal polyps are soft, edematous, and usually bilateral, associated with allergy or chronic rhinosinusitis. They don’t have a verrucous or wart-like appearance, and they arise from the middle meatus, not the vestibule.

 

 

Option C. Inverted papilloma; medial maxillectomy via endoscopic approach: Incorrect. Inverted papilloma arises from the lateral nasal wall (middle meatus), shows inward stromal growth, and is typically larger and more aggressive than squamous papillomas.

 

 

Option D. Rhinosporidiosis; wide excision and dapsone therapy: Incorrect. Rhinosporidiosis presents as vascular, bleeding, polypoidal masses that often arise from the nasopharynx or nasal mucosa and contain sporangia. They are not verrucous in appearance and do not arise from the vestibule.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Squamous papilloma is a wart-like lesion arising from the nasal vestibule or septum, treated by local excision with cauterization to prevent recurrence; laser or cryosurgery may also be used.

 

Ref: Dhingra PL, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, 6th Ed., pg 202

choices.text: Capillary haemangioma; local excision with a cuff of mucoperichondrium
Cavernous haemangioma; wide excision with preoperative embolization
Inverted papilloma; medial maxillectomy via endoscopic approach
Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma; radiotherapy and endoscopic resection

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with intermittent nasal obstruction and episodes of recurrent epistaxis from the left nostril for the past few weeks. On anterior rhinoscopy, a soft, dark red, pedunculated mass is noted on the anterior part of the nasal septum. The mass is smooth but partially ulcerated. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis and appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Capillary haemangioma; local excision with a cuff of mucoperichondrium

 

Also known as bleeding polypus of the septum, capillary haemangioma arises from the anterior nasal septum, is soft, dark red, pedunculated or sessile, and may become ulcerated, presenting with epistaxis and nasal obstruction. Treatment is local excision along with a cuff of surrounding mucoperichondrium to minimize recurrence.

 

 

Option B. Cavernous haemangioma; wide excision with preoperative embolization: Incorrect. Cavernous haemangiomas arise from the turbinates on the lateral wall, not the anterior septum. They may require cryotherapy, radiotherapy, or surgical excision depending on extent, but this case fits capillary type.

 

 

Option C. Inverted papilloma; medial maxillectomy via endoscopic approach: Incorrect. Inverted papilloma arises from the middle meatus/lateral wall, shows inward stromal growth, and is not soft or red in appearance. It doesn't typically present with recurrent epistaxis alone.

 

 

Option D. Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma; radiotherapy and endoscopic resection: Incorrect. JNA occurs in adolescent males, arises from the sphenopalatine foramen, and causes profuse epistaxis and nasopharyngeal mass, not a pedunculated lesion on the septum.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Capillary haemangioma (bleeding polypus of septum) presents as a soft red mass on anterior septum with recurrent epistaxis and is treated by local excision with a cuff of mucoperichondrium.

 

Ref: Dhingra PL, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, 6th Edition, pg 203

choices.text: Wide surgical excision due to risk of malignant transformation
Conservative endoscopic debulking with serial follow-up
Radiotherapy to reduce the tumor size before surgery
Observation alone, as chondromas are always benign

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with progressive nasal obstruction and a sensation of fullness in the nasal cavity. On nasal endoscopy, a firm, lobulated mass is seen arising from the nasal septum, extending posteriorly. CT imaging reveals a well-defined, non-calcified lesion. Biopsy confirms a pure chondroma. The ENT surgeon is concerned about future risk of malignant transformation due to the patient's prior history of multiple endoscopic excisions for similar masses. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wide surgical excision due to risk of malignant transformation

 

Chondromas can arise from the ethmoid, nasal cavity, or septum, and are usually smooth, firm, and lobulated. While typically benign, recurrent or large tumors can undergo malignant transformation, especially after repeated surgical interference. Hence, wide surgical excision is the treatment of choice in such cases.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Conservative endoscopic debulking with serial follow-up: Incorrect. While acceptable for very small or first-time lesions, conservative debulking is not recommended in recurrent or large chondromas due to the malignant potential. This approach risks incomplete removal and further recurrences.

 

Option C. Radiotherapy to reduce the tumor size before surgery: Incorrect. Radiotherapy is not recommended in benign cartilage tumors like chondromas and may increase the risk of malignant transformation. Surgery is the definitive management.

 

Option D. Observation alone, as chondromas are always benign: Incorrect. Chondromas have potential for malignant transformation, particularly when recurrent or if inadequately excised. Observation alone is inappropriate for such cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nasal chondromas are firm, lobulated tumors arising from septum or ethmoid, and require wide excision in recurrent or large lesions due to risk of malignant transformation.

 

Ref: Dhingra PL, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, 6th Edition, pg 203

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought by his parents with concerns of a midline pit over the nasal dorsum noted since birth. The opening occasionally discharges material and has hair protruding from it. On examination, there is widening of the upper nasal septum, splaying of the nasal bones, and hypertelorism. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nasal dermoid

 

Nasal dermoid cysts/sinuses are congenital midline lesions that may present with a pit or sinus in the midline nasal dorsum, often with hair protruding from the opening. Features include widening of the upper nasal septum, splaying of nasal bones, and sometimes hypertelorism. Early diagnosis is important to prevent intracranial complications, and imaging is used to assess extent.

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Encephalocele: Incorrect. A nasal encephalocele also presents in the midline, but usually has a compressible swelling, may transilluminate, and shows pulsations or increases in size with crying (positive Furstenberg test). It does not have hair or a pit with discharge.

 

 

Option C. Capillary haemangioma: Incorrect. Also called bleeding polypus of the septum, this appears as a dark red, soft, vascular mass, usually not congenital and not associated with midline pits or bony deformities like hypertelorism.
