Option D. Nasal glioma: Incorrect. Nasal gliomas are firm, non-compressible congenital masses composed of ectopic glial tissue, often lateral or extranasal. They do not have a pit or hair protrusion, and are not associated with splaying of nasal bones.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nasal dermoid presents as a midline nasal pit with hair, widening of upper nasal septum, splaying of nasal bones, and hypertelorism.

 

Ref: Dhingra PL, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, 6th Edition, pg 203

choices.text: Squamous cell carcinoma of nasal vestibule; commonly metastasizes to parotid nodes
Adenocarcinoma of lateral wall; arises from minor salivary glands
Septal squamous cell carcinoma; also called "nose-picker's cancer"
Adenoid cystic carcinoma of nasal septum; highly aggressive with nodal spread

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents with complaints of burning sensation and soreness inside the nose, along with nasal obstruction for the past few weeks. He has a long-standing habit of nasal picking. On anterior rhinoscopy, a lesion is noted at the mucocutaneous junction of the nasal septum. Biopsy confirms low-grade squamous cell carcinoma. There is no evidence of lymph node metastasis or sinus involvement. Which of the following best describes the most likely diagnosis and common name for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Septal squamous cell carcinoma; also called "nose-picker's cancer"

 

This lesion arises from the mucocutaneous junction of the nasal septum, a common site in older men, especially those with chronic nasal trauma like nose picking—hence termed “nose-picker’s cancer.” It is usually a low-grade squamous cell carcinoma, and metastasis is rare.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Squamous cell carcinoma of nasal vestibule; commonly metastasizes to parotid nodes: Incorrect. While vestibular squamous cell carcinoma is a recognized type, it arises from the lateral wall of the nasal vestibule and may spread to the columella, floor, upper lip, and parotid nodes. However, the lesion described is septal, not vestibular.

 

Option B. Adenocarcinoma of lateral wall; arises from minor salivary glands: Incorrect. Adenocarcinoma arises from glands of the mucous membrane or minor salivary glands, most often involving the upper part of the lateral wall, not the septum or mucocutaneous junction.

 

Option D. Adenoid cystic carcinoma of nasal septum; highly aggressive with nodal spread: Incorrect. Adenoid cystic carcinoma typically arises from glands in the lateral wall, not the septum. Though it can be aggressive, nodal spread is less common, and this is not the best fit for the described case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Squamous cell carcinoma of the nasal septum, commonly called “nose-picker’s cancer,” arises from the mucocutaneous junction and is usually a low-grade malignancy.

 

Ref: Dhingra PL, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, 6th Edition, pg 204

choices.text: Most commonly arises from lateral wall of the nasal cavity and shows good response to radiotherapy
Frequently affects children and shows spontaneous regression
Commonly arises from anterior nasal septum; spreads via lymphatics and blood; best treated by wide surgical excision
Pigmentation is always present; cervical lymphadenopathy is rare at diagnosis

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents with progressive nasal obstruction and recurrent episodes of epistaxis for the past few months. On anterior rhinoscopy, a bluish-black polypoidal mass is visualized arising from the anterior nasal septum. Biopsy confirms malignant melanoma. No lymphadenopathy is detected at present. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Commonly arises from anterior nasal septum; spreads via lymphatics and blood; best treated by wide surgical excision

 

Malignant melanoma in the nasal cavity commonly arises from the anterior nasal septum, and can also involve the middle and inferior turbinates. It presents as a slaty-grey or bluish-black polypoidal mass. The tumor spreads via lymphatics and hematogenous routes, with cervical nodal metastasis sometimes present at initial examination. Wide surgical excision is the mainstay of treatment, as radiotherapy and chemotherapy are avoided due to their immune-suppressive effects. 

 

The 5-year survival after surgery is around 30%.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Most commonly arises from lateral wall of the nasal cavity and shows good response to radiotherapy: Incorrect. While some nasal tumors may arise from the lateral wall, malignant melanoma most frequently arises from the anterior nasal septum, not the lateral wall. Additionally, radiotherapy is avoided because it suppresses the immune response, which plays a critical role in controlling melanoma.

 

Option B. Frequently affects children and shows spontaneous regression: Incorrect. Malignant melanoma usually affects individuals above 50 years, and not children. Spontaneous regression is not characteristic of nasal mucosal melanoma, which is aggressive.

 

Option D. Pigmentation is always present; cervical lymphadenopathy is rare at diagnosis: Incorrect. Some melanomas can be amelanotic (nonpigmented), and cervical nodal metastasis may already be present at the time of first presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Malignant melanoma of the nasal cavity typically arises from the anterior nasal septum, spreads via lymphatics and blood, and is best managed with wide surgical excision due to poor response to radiotherapy.

 

Ref: Dhingra PL, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, 6th Edition, pg 204

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents with complaints of progressive unilateral nasal obstruction and intermittent episodes of epistaxis for the past two months. He recently started experiencing headaches and occasional diplopia. On anterior rhinoscopy, a friable cherry-red polypoidal mass is visualized in the upper third of the nasal cavity. High-resolution CT reveals erosion of the cribriform plate, and MRI shows extension into the orbit. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Esthesioneuroblastoma

 

Also known as olfactory neuroblastoma, this rare tumor arises from the olfactory epithelium in the upper third of the nasal cavity, most often presenting with unilateral nasal obstruction and epistaxis. Advanced disease may invade the orbit and cribriform plate, producing proptosis, headache, diplopia, and blurred vision. Imaging (CT/MRI) helps assess extent before biopsy due to vascularity. Histopathology can show pseudorosettes (low grade) or pleomorphic cells (high grade). Treatment often includes craniofacial resection with adjuvant therapy.

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma: Incorrect. This is a highly vascular tumor typically affecting adolescent males, presenting with nasopharyngeal mass, recurrent epistaxis, and nasal obstruction. However, JNA originates in the nasopharynx, not from the olfactory epithelium or upper nasal cavity, and does not invade the cribriform plate early.

 

 

Option C. Nasal polyp: Incorrect. Nasal polyps are non-vascular, pale, edematous masses, often bilateral, associated with allergic rhinitis or sinusitis. They do not bleed easily, lack invasion, and are not associated with orbital or intracranial extension.

 

 

Option D. Inverted papilloma: Incorrect. A benign tumor with potential for malignant transformation, often arising from the lateral nasal wall, and commonly presenting with unilateral nasal obstruction. While locally aggressive, cranial or orbital invasion is rare, and the tumor typically appears pinkish and non-friable.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Esthesioneuroblastoma is a vascular tumor arising from the olfactory epithelium in the upper third of the nasal cavity, commonly presenting with unilateral nasal obstruction and epistaxis, and requires craniofacial resection for treatment.

 

Ref: Dhingra PL, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, 6th Edition. pg 204

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with recurrent episodes of epistaxis for the past 3 weeks. There is no history of trauma, hypertension, or anticoagulant use. On nasal endoscopy, a vascular mass is noted in the posterior nasal cavity. A biopsy attempt leads to brisk bleeding, and the procedure is aborted. Imaging shows a well-circumscribed lesion. Histology reveals a tumor of vascular origin with no clear distinction between benign and malignant features. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hemangiopericytoma

 

This is a rare vascular tumor that arises from pericytes, which are cells surrounding capillaries. It typically presents in older adults (60–70 years) with recurrent epistaxis. Brisk bleeding on biopsy is a hallmark due to its vascular nature. Histologically, it is not possible to distinguish between benign and malignant forms, making clinical behavior and recurrence more important in management. The mainstay of treatment is wide surgical excision, while radiotherapy is reserved for inoperable or recurrent lesions.

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma: Incorrect. Although also a vascular tumor, this occurs exclusively in adolescent males, and arises from the nasopharynx, not the posterior nasal cavity of elderly patients.

 

 

Option C. Capillary hemangioma: Incorrect. This is a benign vascular lesion, usually seen in children or young adults, and often involves the anterior nasal septum. It typically doesn’t bleed profusely like hemangiopericytoma and doesn’t occur in older individuals.

 

Option D. Inverted papilloma: Incorrect. This is a benign epithelial tumor, not of vascular origin. It may cause nasal obstruction or discharge, and occurs in middle-aged adults, but does not typically cause brisk bleeding on biopsy and is not related to pericytes.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hemangiopericytoma is a rare vascular tumor arising from pericytes, typically seen in elderly patients with epistaxis, characterized by brisk bleeding on biopsy and treated with wide surgical excision.

 

Ref: Dhingra PL, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, 6th Edition pg.204

choices.text: Start antibiotics for presumed acute sinusitis
Perform diagnostic nasal endoscopy to look for foreign body
Order a CT scan of the paranasal sinuses
Reassure the parent and observe the child for spontaneous resolution

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought to the ENT OPD with a 6-day history of unilateral, foul-smelling nasal discharge that is occasionally blood-stained. There is no history of trauma or upper respiratory tract infection. Anterior rhinoscopy reveals crusting and mucopurulent discharge in the right nasal cavity. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Perform diagnostic nasal endoscopy to look for foreign body

 

The clinical dictum is: “If a child presents with unilateral, foul-smelling nasal discharge, a nasal foreign body must be excluded.” Diagnostic nasal endoscopy allows direct visualization, especially in cases where the object is lodged deep or the history is unclear. It is the most appropriate next step.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Start antibiotics for presumed acute sinusitis: Incorrect. Although sinusitis can present with nasal discharge, unilateral, foul-smelling, blood-stained discharge in a child is highly suggestive of a nasal foreign body. Empirical treatment without evaluating the underlying cause would delay proper management.

 

Option C. Order a CT scan of the paranasal sinuses: Incorrect. CT is not first-line in this case. A plain X-ray might be used if a radio-opaque foreign body is suspected, but endoscopy is preferred for both diagnosis and removal. CT is reserved for complicated cases with suspicion of sinusitis, orbital, or intracranial spread.

 

Option D. Reassure the parent and observe the child for spontaneous resolution: Incorrect. This would risk retained foreign body complications like rhinolith formation, nasal infection, and inhalation into the airway. Prompt removal is essential to prevent morbidity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A child with unilateral, foul-smelling, blood-stained nasal discharge must be evaluated for a nasal foreign body using diagnostic endoscopy, as retained objects can lead to infection, rhinoliths, or airway inhalation.

 

Ref: Dhingra PL, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, 6th Edition pg.161

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents with unilateral nasal obstruction and foul-smelling nasal discharge for the past several months. She occasionally notices blood-streaked mucus and has recently developed facial pain. On anterior rhinoscopy, a hard, irregular, greyish-black mass is noted between the septum and inferior turbinate. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rhinolith

 

A rhinolith forms when a foreign body, blood clot, or inspissated secretion becomes a nidus for slow deposition of calcium and magnesium salts, leading to a brittle, stony-hard mass. It typically presents in adults with unilateral nasal obstruction, foul-smelling, blood-stained discharge, and sometimes neuralgic pain. The hard, irregular mass with a grey-brown or greenish-black color is classic. Removal often requires general anaesthesia, and large rhinoliths may need to be broken or even removed by lateral rhinotomy.

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Inverted papilloma: Incorrect. Inverted papillomas are benign epithelial tumors arising from the lateral nasal wall, typically presenting as pinkish or reddish masses. They may cause obstruction or bleeding, but lack the stony hard feel and irregular calcified surface typical of a rhinolith.

 

 

Option B. Nasal foreign body: Incorrect.Nasal foreign bodies are more common in children and usually have a shorter history of nasal obstruction and discharge. Chronic foreign bodies may serve as a nidus for rhinolith formation, but once encrusted with salts and hardened, the entity is termed rhinolith, not just a foreign body.

 

Option D. Fungal sinusitis: Incorrect. Allergic fungal sinusitis can present with nasal obstruction and thick discharge, but the mass is often described as peanut butter-like or cheesy, not stony hard. It also typically involves sinus opacification and nasal polyps, rather than a discrete encrusted mass.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A rhinolith is a calcified, stony-hard mass formed around a foreign body in the nasal cavity, presenting with unilateral foul-smelling discharge, and is managed by surgical removal, often under general anaesthesia.

 

Ref: Dhingra PL, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, 6th Edition. pg.161

questions.text: A 62-year-old man from rural India presents in September with complaints of foul-smelling nasal discharge, nasal obstruction, and a crawling sensation inside his nose. He is a known case of atrophic rhinitis. On examination, multiple wriggling larvae are seen in the nasal cavity, with signs of mucosal destruction. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nasal myiasis

 

Nasal myiasis is an infestation of the nasal cavity by the larval forms of flies, especially those from the genus Chrysomyia. It typically occurs in patients with foul-smelling nasal discharge, such as those with atrophic rhinitis, syphilis, leprosy, or infected wounds. Flies are attracted to this odor, laying around 200 eggs, which hatch into larvae within 24 hours. The condition is more prevalent in India during August to October. Clinical findings include live maggots, mucosal destruction, and potential extension into deeper structures.

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Allergic fungal sinusitis: Incorrect. Presents with nasal polyps, thick allergic mucin, and a history of allergic rhinitis or asthma. There are no live organisms like larvae in this condition. It does not cause crawling sensation or visible maggots.

 

 

Option C. Rhinosporidiosis: Incorrect. Caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi, presenting with strawberry-like, vascular polypoidal masses with white dots (sporangia). It does not involve larvae or foul-smelling discharge and is unrelated to seasonal fly infestations.

 

 

Option D. Rhinolith: Incorrect. A stone-like mass formed by mineral deposition around a foreign body. While it can cause foul-smelling discharge, it is not associated with larvae or a crawling sensation.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nasal myiasis is caused by infestation of fly larvae (usually Chrysomyia species) in the nasal cavity, especially in patients with foul-smelling discharge from conditions like atrophic rhinitis, and is commonly seen in India between August and October.

 

Ref: Dhingra PL, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, 6th Edition. pg.161

choices.text: Isolation, mechanical removal of maggots, chloroform oil instillation, and nasal hygiene
Order urgent MRI brain and start antitubercular therapy

questions.text: A 60-year-old man from rural India presents with complaints of headache, sneezing, and thin blood-stained nasal discharge for 3 days. He has a history of atrophic rhinitis. On examination, puffiness of the eyelids and lips is noted. On the 4th day, several larvae are seen crawling out of the nasal cavity, and a foul odor surrounds the patient. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Isolation, mechanical removal of maggots, chloroform oil instillation, and nasal hygiene

 

This is the standard management of nasal myiasis:

 

  • Mechanical removal of maggots with forceps.
  • Chloroform in water or oil is instilled to kill and flush out larvae that retreat from light.
  • Warm saline nasal douching removes slough, crusts, and dead tissue.
  • Isolation and use of mosquito nets is important to prevent fly contact and reinfestation.
  • Patients must be taught proper nasal hygiene to prevent recurrence.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Start empirical antifungal therapy: Incorrect. There is no indication of fungal sinusitis (e.g., allergic mucin, nasal polyps, eosinophilia). This case clearly points to nasal myiasis, which is not fungal in origin, but caused by fly larvae infestation.

 

Option B. Nasal packing and IV steroids: Incorrect. This may be done in epistaxis or nasal trauma, but nasal packing would worsen the condition by trapping maggots and increasing necrosis. Steroids have no role here and can impair local immunity.

 

Option D. Order urgent MRI brain and start antitubercular therapy: Incorrect. There's no clinical evidence of tuberculosis or need for imaging at this stage. While severe untreated myiasis may cause intracranial spread and meningitis, that is a late complication. Initial focus should be on removing the maggots and controlling local tissue destruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nasal myiasis presents with blood-stained discharge, facial swelling, and larvae in the nasal cavity, and is managed by isolation, mechanical removal of maggots, chloroform oil instillation, nasal douching, and hygiene education.

 

Ref: Dhingra PL, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, 6th Edition. pg.161

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with complaints of progressive nasal obstruction and persistent nasal discharge. She underwent endoscopic sinus surgery and nasal packing 3 months ago. Nasal endoscopy reveals fibrous adhesions between the septum and the inferior turbinate. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nasal synechia

 

Nasal synechia refers to adhesion formation between the nasal septum and the turbinates, typically due to injury or inflammation of opposing mucosal surfaces. It often follows intranasal procedures such as:

 

  • Septal surgery
  • Polypectomy
  • Endoscopic sinus surgery
  • Removal of foreign bodies
  • Intranasal packing or nasal fracture reduction

 

Clinical features include nasal obstruction, headache, and sinusitis, due to impaired drainage. Diagnosis is confirmed by nasal endoscopy.

 

 

Other Options: 

Option B. Inverted papilloma: Incorrect. This is a benign epithelial tumor, typically presenting as a unilateral mass, with nasal obstruction and bleeding. It doesn’t form adhesions or follow trauma/surgery.

 

 

Option C. Choanal atresia: Incorrect. A congenital condition where the posterior nasal passage is blocked. It presents in infants with cyanosis relieved by crying, not in adults post-surgery.

 

Option D. Allergic rhinitis: Incorrect. Presents with sneezing, nasal itching, watery discharge, and pale boggy mucosa. It does not cause adhesions between septum and turbinates.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nasal synechia is an adhesion between the nasal septum and turbinate due to mucosal injury, commonly following intranasal surgeries, and presents with nasal obstruction and sinusitis.

 

Ref: Dhingra PL, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, 6th Edition. pg.161

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with a history of septoplasty 6 weeks ago now presents with nasal obstruction. Nasal endoscopy reveals fibrous adhesion between the septum and inferior turbinate, consistent with nasal synechia. What is the next best step in management to prevent recurrence after excision of the adhesion?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Insert a silastic or cellophane sheet between the raw surfaces

 

This is the standard method to prevent reformation of synechiae. After excising the adhesion, a thin silastic or cellophane sheet is placed between the opposing raw mucosal surfaces, preventing direct contact during healing. The sheet is changed every 2–3 days until complete mucosal healing occurs.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Cauterize both mucosal surfaces and allow secondary healing: Incorrect. Cauterization may worsen mucosal damage and increase the risk of further adhesion formation, especially if both opposing surfaces are left raw.

 

Option B. Place intranasal pack and remove after 2 weeks: Incorrect. While intranasal packing may temporarily keep surfaces apart, prolonged packing can lead to infection and additional trauma. Also, packs are not changed every 2–3 days like silastic sheets.

 

Option D. Apply steroid spray to reduce inflammation: Incorrect. Although helpful in inflammatory conditions like allergic rhinitis, steroid sprays do not prevent mechanical adhesion between healing surfaces after surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Post-excision of nasal synechia, placing a silastic or cellophane sheet between raw mucosal surfaces and changing it every 2–3 days prevents recurrence by avoiding re-adhesion.

 

Ref: Dhingra PL, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, 6th Edition. pg.161
